summary: The 'Veterans Exposed to Toxic PFAS Act' (VET PFAS Act) amends Title 38 of the United States Code to provide hospital care and medical services to veterans and their dependents stationed at military installations where they were exposed to per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). It includes specific conditions linked to PFAS exposure, like high cholesterol and certain cancers, and allows for the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to add conditions based on scientific studies. The bill also grants a presumption of service connection for certain veterans exposed to PFAS, making it easier to receive disability benefits. It also provides healthcare for family members.
